{{Infobox person |name= Daniel Vila |image= |alias = El Diablo |nationality = [[Argentina]] |weight= |height= |birth_name = Daniel Eduardo Vila |birth_date ={{birth date and age|1953|6|1|df=y}} |birth_place =[[Mendoza, Argentina|Mendoza]], [[Argentina]] |home_town= |website= {{url|www.twitter.com/danielevila}} |}}
'''Daniel Eduardo Vila''' ([[Mendoza, Argentina|Mendoza]], June 1 of 1953) is an [[entrepreneur]], former [[sports director]] and [[lawyer]] in [[Argentina]]. He is president of America TV and Radio La Red, besides being the owner of the media [[Grupo América]], in partnership with the former politician [[Jose Luis Manzano|José Luis Manzano]]. He is also owner of Journal One, a leading newspaper published in [[Mendoza, Argentina|Mendoza]], [[Santa Fe, Argentina|Santa Fe]], [[Entre Ríos Province|Entre Rios]] and [[Rosario, Santa Fe|Rosario]]. He is also president of Diario La Capital de Rosario and president of [[Club Sportivo Independiente Rivadavia]] of [[Mendoza, Argentina|Mendoza]].
== Biography ==
Vila is a [[lawyer]], is divorced and has six children. Since 2011 is with the [[model (fashion)|model]] and [[Television presenter|presenter]] [[Pamela David]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.diarioshow.com/notas/2011/02/09/52805-pamela-david---daniel-vila-amor-confirmado.html |title=Pamela David, Daniel Vila. Love confirmed |location=[[Argentina]] |author=DiarioShow.com |date=9 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131112165842/http://www.diarioshow.com/notas/2011/02/09/52805-pamela-david---daniel-vila-amor-confirmado.html |archivedate=2013-11-12 |df= }}</ref> is a shareholder and chairman of several media, energy and real estate category.
He is accompanied in most business his brother [[Alfredo Luis Vila]] and former MP and Minister of Interior Menem (turned entrepreneur) [[Jose Luis Manzano|José Luis Manzano]]. He began his media business in 1983 when it acquired Radio Nihuil of [[Mendoza, Argentina|Mendoza]].
In 1985 developed Supercanal SA with more than 500,000 subscribers in 17 provinces. In 1993 he founded his first day in Mendoza, which he called Journal UNO. It was followed by buying “The Capital” of Rosario, UNO Entre Ríos and Santa Fe.
The Group also has radios [[AM broadcasting|AM]] and FM, being emblematic [[Radio Network]], with repeaters throughout the country and national television. “America” is a TV channel that is distributed throughout the country and abroad, and “A24” is a news cable signal nationally distributed. With the company Arlink UNO Media provides telecommunications services such as value-added broadband.
Vila also chairs foundations “La Capital” and “Vendimia Solidaria”. The latter collects annually about a million and a half dollars, which are used for works of social support. He was also president of the Board of Directors of the University of Congress from 2001 to 2003. In the energy sector, his company Andes Energy is associated to [[YPF]] in the exploration and development of more than 30 oil areas in eight provinces of Argentina. He is also a shareholder and Edelar and Edemsa, both electricity distributors in [[Mendoza, Argentina|Mendoza]] and [[La Rioja, Argentina|La Rioja]] respectively.
== Activity in sports ==
Vila was Chair of the Club Sportivo Independiente Rivadavia of [[Mendoza, Argentina|Mendoza]] from 2005 to 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=04rW4PHE9ns|title=Interview Canal A24| author=Youtube|accessdate=October 4, 2011|date=27 September 2011}}</ref> while trying push a bill to "democratize " the [[Argentine Football]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leydelfutbol.com/index.php/quienesSomos| title=Proposed Law to democratize the Argentine Football|accessdate=October 4, 2011|author=Act Football|year=2010}}</ref>
On Tuesday October 18, 2011 he was appointed President of [[Argentine Football Association|AFA]] by provincial clubs of [[Football]], which obtained court authorization to vote for him in an assembly in which the current officials sector reelected its president more than three decades, [[Julio Grondona]].
This confusing situation awaits the definition of justice to find out who was legitimately elected to chair the [[Argentine Football Association]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.elintransigente.com/notas/2011/10/18/daniel-habria-elegido-presidente-asamblea-paralela-107414.asp|title=Daniel Vila have been elected as President of the AFA, in a parallel assembly|author=El Intransigente|date=8 October 2011|accessdate=18 October 2011}}</ref>
==Academic life==
Vila was [[Chairman]] of the Board of Directors of the University of Congress during 2001-2003. He is currently a [[professor]] at the same [[university]] where he teaches the "Media and Public Opinion" course. This gets him frequently traveling from [[Buenos Aires]] to [[Mendoza, Argentina|Mendoza City]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.perfil.com/elespia/A-los-52-aos-Sergio-Berni-cambiara-armas-por-chupete-y-baberos-20140503-0086.html|title=Daniel Vila da clases a universitarios.|author = Perfil.com|date = 3 May 2014|accessdate=3 May 2014}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}

{{Infobox Newspaper | name = ''Donya-e-Eqtesad'' | image = Donya-e-Eqtesad_Logo.jpg | caption = | type = Daily [[newspaper]] | format = Broadsheet | foundation = {{start date and age|2002}} | ceased publication = | price = 20 cents | owners = [[Alireza Bakhtiari]] | political position = Center-right | publisher = DEN Group | editor = Ali Mirzakhani | staff = 200 | circulation = 50,000 | language = [[Persian language|Persian]] | headquarters = [[Tehran]], [[Iran]] | sister newspapers = [[Financial Tribune]] (in [[English language|English]])
[[Tejarat-e-Farda]] (in [[Persian language|Persian]]) | ISSN = | website = {{URL|http://www.donya-e-eqtesad.com}} }} '''''Donya-e-Eqtesad''''' ({{lang-fa|دنیای اقتصاد}} meaning "World of Economics" in Persian) is a daily [[newspaper]]. ==History and profile== [[File:Maryam Mirzakhani s Pic on a Iranian Newspaper.jpg|thumb|[[Maryam Mirzakhani]]'s picture on the Donya-e-Eqtesad's cover]] ''Donya-e-Eqtesad'' was founded in October 2002, and it has been published and circulated in [[Iran]] since then.[http://www.donya-e-eqtesad.com/ official website] This economic daily is among the most circulated newspapers in Iran.[http://www.payvand.com/news/09/dec/1164.html 100 top Iranian brands] ''Payvand''. December 2009. Donya-e-Eqtesad is considered to be an advocate of free markets, and does not have any formal affiliation with the [[government of Iran]]. It is a moderate critique of the government economic policies. Its main competitor was ''[[Sarmayeh]]'' newspaper. ''Donya-e-Eqtesad'' regularly contains editorial articles, analytical comments about the domestic as well as the world's economy, [[Industry of Iran|industry]] and [[Mining in Iran|mines]], international oil and [[energy in Iran|energy markets]], [[banking in Iran]], commerce and [[Tourism in Iran|tourism]], and the latest news from [[Tehran Stock Exchange]]. ''Donya-e-Eqtesad'' also publishes special reports on [[Transport in Iran|transportation]] and [[Agriculture in Iran|agriculture]] and covers the latest developments in [[Petroleum industry in Iran|oil exploration and exploitation operations]] as well as other related economic subjects. ==See also== *[[List of newspapers in Iran]] *[[Economy of Iran]] *[[Media of Iran]] *[[Financial Tribune]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.donya-e-eqtesad.com/ Donya-e-Eqtesad website] [[Category:Newspapers published in Iran]] [[Category:Publications established in 2002]] [[Category:2002 establishments in Iran]] [[Category:Persian-language newspapers]] [[Category:Business newspapers]] {{Iran-stub}}

[[File:Oppenheimer1945.jpg|thumb|Ernest Oppenheimer (right) visiting a diamond factory (Amsterdam, Dec. 1945)]]
'''Sir Ernest Oppenheimer''' (22 May 1880 – 25 November 1957) was a [[diamond]] and [[gold]] mining entrepreneur, [[financier]] and [[philanthropist]],<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.za/books?id=YxH9CLm2K6sC|title=In Good Company: An Anatomy of Corporate Social Responsibility|last=Rajak|first=Dinah|date=2011-11-09|publisher=Stanford University Press|isbn=9780804781619|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.za/books?id=YrPIDAAAQBAJ|title=Corporate Social Responsibility: Academic Insights and Impacts|last=Vertigans|first=Stephen|last2=Idowu|first2=Samuel O.|date=2016-08-02|publisher=Springer|isbn=9783319350837|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Ernest-Oppenheimer|title=Sir Ernest Oppenheimer {{!}} South African industrialist|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2017-11-15|language=en}}</ref> who controlled [[De Beers Consolidated Mines|De Beers]] and founded the [[Anglo American plc|Anglo American Corporation]] of [[South Africa]].
==Career== He was born in [[Friedberg, Hesse|Friedberg]], Germany, the son of Edward Oppenheimer, a [[cigar]] merchant. Oppenheimer began his working life at 17, when he entered Dunkelsbuhler & Company, a diamond brokerage in [[London]]. His efforts impressed his employer and in 1902, at the age of 22, he was sent to South Africa to represent the [[company (law)|company]] as a buyer in [[Kimberley, Northern Cape|Kimberley]], where he eventually rose to the position of mayor.
He became great friends with William Lincoln Honnold, an American engineer and chairman of Transvaal Coal Trust, Brakpan Mines, Springs Mines and The New Era Company.{{cn|date=January 2017}}
In 1917, they launched the Anglo American Corporation with financial assistance from [[J. P. Morgan]]. The initial capital was £1 million. Half of the capital was subscribed in America and half in England and South Africa.<ref>H. F. Oppenheimer, R. B. Hagart, W. D. Wilson, Francis Whitmore, H. MacConachie, Dr. J. E. Holloway, ''[http://www.historicalpapers.wits.ac.za/inventories/inv_pdfo/A1132/A1132-C450-001-jpeg.pdf Optima]'', September 1967 Volume seventeen number three, Commemorates the Fiftieth Anniversary of Anglo American Corporation September 25th 1967, p.97.</ref>
In 1927, Ernest Oppenheimer managed to wrest control of Cecil Rhodes's De Beers empire and built and consolidated the company's global monopoly over the world's diamond industry until his retirement.
He was involved in a number of controversies, including price fixing, [[antitrust]] behaviour and an allegation of not releasing industrial diamonds for the US war effort during [[World War II]].<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=raO8jHBdDhYC|title=Glitter & Greed|author=Janine P. Roberts|isbn=0-9713942-9-6|publisher=The Disinformation Company|year=2003|accessdate=2008-11-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8le1AAAAIAAJ|title=Ernest Oppenheimer and the Economic Development of Southern Africa|author=Theodor Emanuel Gregory|publisher=Arno Press|year=1977|accessdate=2008-11-27}}</ref>
He died in [[Johannesburg]] in 1957. He was born into a [[Jew]]ish family, but as an adult, he converted to [[Anglicanism]] and was buried at St George's Church, [[Parktown, Gauteng|Parktown]]. He was succeeded in the business by his son [[Harry Oppenheimer]]. Oppenheimer's brother, [[Bernard Oppenheimer|Sir Bernard Oppenheimer]], was also heavily involved in the diamond industry.
In 1964, the [[Oppenheimer Diamond]] was named in his honour by its owner, [[Harry Winston]], who donated the stone (not a [[Gemstone|gem]], as it remains uncut and unpolished) to the [[Smithsonian Institution]] as a memorial.
==See also== * [[Gustav Imroth]] * [[Joel family]] * [[Cecil Rhodes]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.debeersgroup.com/en/our-story/our-history.html|title=Our History - De Beers Group|website=www.debeersgroup.com}}</ref>

'''Forward Music''' is a [[Lebanon]] based [[independent record label]] specializing in [[World Music]].<ref>[http://www.beirut.com/Media/Saqiyat-El-Janzir/Forward-Music/6666 Forward Music :: Beirut.com :: Beirut City Guide<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
{{Infobox company | name = Forward Music S.A.L. | logo = [[Image:Forward Music Logo 2011 OrangeBG.jpg|230px|Forward Music logo]] | type = [[Private company|Private]] | foundation = 2001<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.prweb.com/releases/2004/10/prweb173000.htm World Music from Lebanon. Three New Arabic/Brazilian Fusion CDs<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> | location_city = Beirut | location_country = Lebanon | key_people = [[Ghazi Abdel Baki]] | area_served = | industry = [[Music industry|Music entertainment]] | homepage = {{url|forwardmusic.net}}}}
== History == Forward Music was established in 2001 by Ghazi Abdel Baki as a music label that pools together the cooperative efforts of young artists from the Middle East. It aims to encourage new and creative trends in the musical arts, blending the various cultural currents that meet and interact in new fusions and fresh perspectives. It hopes to draw on the rich musical past of the Arab world and the array of contemporary influences to find new musical dialects. Forward Music is committed to making an authentic contribution to our ever-changing culture and to the growing global dialogue of World Music.
Today, Forward Music is a leading independent label that produces and distributes the work of more than 30 of the most respected musicians and singers in the Middle East.<ref>forwardmusic.net</ref>
In 2007, one of Forward Music's projects, "Al Muwashahat", received The [[BBC]] [[Awards for world music]] .<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio3/worldmusic/a4wm2007/2007_ghada_shbeir.shtml BBC - Awards for World Music 2007 - Ghada Shbeir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
In October 2010, Forward Music acquired 13 album licenses from the record label Incognito, further expanding its music catalogue.<ref>[http://www.iloubnan.info/en/actualite/id/52481http://www.prweb.com/releases/2004/10/prweb173000.htm Forward Music and Incognito announce the consolidation of their businesses - iloubnan.info<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Later, In 2011, Forward Music opened its state of the art Live concert venue in Beirut: The Democratic republic of Music (DRM). Despite the incredible difficulties of the period in Lebanon, DRM hosted 300 concerts in the span of 3 years with artists such as: Stanley Jordan, Tony Allen, The Musicians of the Nile, Henry Texier, Souad Massi, The Herbalizer, Ilham El Madfaii, Joey De Francesco, and many others including the label's artists and a myriad of musicians from Syria, Egypt, Tunisia, Jordan, Iraq, and Lebanon.<ref>{{cite web|authors=Time Out Beirut, Night Life, Entertainment, Travel, nightlife, sports, Beirut, Lebanon, photos, gallery, Photo Gallery, Clubs, Restaurants, Pubs, Bars, Hotels, Coffee, Resorts, Film, Music, DVD, fashion, Cinema, Art, Books, Stage, Performing Arts, Shopping |url=http://www.timeoutbeirut.com/music-festivals/article/6060/democratic-republic-of-music.html |title=Democratic Republic of Music » Music & Festivals |publisher=Time Out Beirut |date= |accessdate=2011-08-03}}</ref>
== List of artists currently on the roster==
*[[Charbel Rouhana]] *Lena Chamamyan *Soumaya Baalbaki *[[Ghazi Abdel Baki]] *Issa Ghandour *[[Mustafa Said]] *Ziyad Sahhab *Ziad El Ahmadie

revision.text:
'''Gerardo Arturo González Sü''' (March 02, 1984) is a Mexican entrepreneur.
==Early years==
Gonzalez was born in [[Guadalajara City]] and had early childhood in [[Dallas, Texas]]. He studied firstly at [[TEC de Monterrey]] Campus Guadalajara International Negotiations. Afterwards, he would study in [[ESC Dijon]] where he would do his international studies at an Exchange Program.
==Biography==
Back in Guadalajara, he worked at a local television program called "[[Bodas+Modas TV]]". Aside his journalistic work, he has also been judge of many beauty pageant contests such as Miss Polonia Webmasters 2006.
==External links== * [http://www.angelfire.com/nb/missmexico/ Miss Mexico Pageant] * [http://www.globmiss.net/pageants/polonia/polonia_globmiss.html/ Miss Polonia Webmasters 2006]

{{For|the American architect|Henry Atherton Frost}} '''Henry Adolph Frost''' (26 June 1844 – 21 July 1909) was a German-born saddler and businessman known for his association with the company which eventually produced the [[Holden]] automobile. His name may have been originally Heinrich Friedrich Adolphe Frost, but he evidently preferred "Adolph Frost".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article41029970 |title=Rhynie |newspaper=[[South Australian Register]] |volume=XXX, |issue=6033 |location=South Australia |date=5 March 1866 |accessdate=27 February 2016 |page=2 |via=National Library of Australia}} He is early referred to as "A. Frost", and later frequently as "H. Adolph Frost"</ref>
==History== Adolph was born in [[Hamburg]], Germany the only son of Johann Joachim Domenicus ( John ) Frost ( 31 MAR 1813 - 14 Dec 1865) and his wife Catharina Maria Louisa Juncken (March 1821 – 11 February 1905), who emigrated to South Australia on the ''Steinwaerder'' (''Steinwärder'') from Hamburg, arriving on the 12th January 1849.
They settled at [[Lyndoch, South Australia|Lyndoch]], and on completion of his schooling learned the skills of the saddler, after which he followed his trade at [[Rhynie, South Australia|Rhynie]], then around 1869 to [[Port Wakefield, South Australia|Port Wakefield]] then [[Yorketown, South Australia|Yorketown]], where he ran a lucrative business, and for a time served as mayor.<ref name=death>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article88298261 |title=Death of Mr. H. A. Frost |newspaper=[[The Chronicle (South Australia)|The Chronicle]] |volume=LII, |issue=2,657 |location=South Australia |date=24 July 1909 |accessdate=27 February 2016 |page=40 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
[[File:Holden & Frost.jpg|thumb|Holden & Frost, 100 Grenfell Street c. 1915]] Around 1879 he moved to Adelaide to take a position with [[J. A. Holden]], who on 1 May 1884<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article39819489 |title=Advertising |newspaper=[[South Australian Register]] |volume=XXXIX, |issue=8590 |location=South Australia |date=28 May 1874 |accessdate=27 February 2016 |page=1 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> took him on as partner in J. A. Holden & Co., which was in a precarious position financially. In August 1885 J. A. Holden sold to his son [[H. J. Holden]] and H. A. Frost his interest in the retail arm of the company,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article44949108 |title=Advertising |newspaper=[[South Australian Register]] |volume=L, |issue=12,092 |location=South Australia |date=15 August 1885 |accessdate=28 February 2016 |page=1 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> which in November 1885 became '''Holden & Frost'''. He sold the wholesale business and his Kensington Park mansion with its extensive grounds. Under the terms of the voluntary liquidation the company continued to operate in the premises at 100 Grenfell Street.
Under the new management the company progressed from the world of saddles and harness to motor vehicle bodies and upholstery.
==Family== *Johann Joachim Domenicus (John) Frost ( 31 MAR 1813 - 14 Dec 1865) and his wife Catharina Maria Louisa Juncken (March 1821 – 11 February 1905) emigrated on the ''Steinwaerder'' (''Steinwärder'') from Hamburg, arriving in SA in 12 January 1849. They had one son and three daughters: :*Henry Adolph Frost (26 June 1844 – 21 July 1909) married (1) Elizabeth James (09 Aug 1849 – 10 April 1892) on 08 July 1866 in Penwortham, South Australia (2) Celia Gray? Grey? (13 August 1861 – 22 April 1912) on 24 May 1893 in The Bible Christian Church,Franklin Street, Adelaide South Australia They had three daughters and five or six sons: <!--sons:13 February 1878, 10 February 1884--> :*Amie? Amy? Frost (26 May 1867 – ) married Edward Welbourn ( – ) on 18 April 1888, lived in Western Australia :*Fannie? Fanney? Frost (10 May 1869 in Port Wakefield – ) married Walter Ernest Aitken ( – ) on 28 March 1889, lived in Hyde Park :*Gertrude Frost (13 December 1873 – ) married (Reuben) Clifton Underwood ( – ) on 8 August 1898, lived at Norwood :*Herbert Adolph Frost (13 February 1878 – 8 September 1910) killed accidentally in Fremantle :*Harold Clare Frost (6 November 1881 at Yorketown – 23 April 1906) :*Gilbert James (James Gilbert?) Frost (10 February 1884 – ) married Maria Bennett "Polly" Jacobs ( – ) on 25 September 1907 :*Raymond Gray? Grey? Frost (20 May 1894 – 6? 7? April 1966) married Lynda Dorothy Atkinson ( – ) on 20 July 1922<!--Agnes Thelma Millar (born 13 April 1894)?--> :*Stuart Clifton Frost (22 April 1896 – 11 May 1966) :*Louis Henry Frost (13 May 1900 – ) <!--perhaps married Rosalie Emily Yeates (1902 – August 1996, buried at Wallaroo) in 1920--> *Louisa Henrietta Caroline Maria Frost (c. 1845 – 25 January 1876) married Robert Swann ( – ) on 1 February 1866 *Caroline Sophia Wilhelmina Frost (c. 1848 – 10 January 1927) married George Wise (1840 – 18 May 1904) on 23 May 1872, lived at Gawler then Norwood. *Mary Ann Frost ( – 29 August 1901) married Hart
== References == {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Frost, H. A.}} [[Category:German emigrants to Australia]] [[Category:Australian businesspeople]] [[Category:Australian coachbuilders]] [[Category:Holden]] [[Category:1844 births]] [[Category:1909 deaths]]

page.title: International Young Publisher of the Year

revision.text:
The '''International Young Publisher of the Year''' is a British Council award programme, which has been developed with the support of the [[London Book Fair]]. It is targeted at [[publishing|publishers]] aged 25 to 35 from emerging economies. The winner receives a free exhibition stand at the next London Book Fair and a financial award. The winner then goes on to develop a publishing project between the UK and their country.
The final of the international competition with eight to ten participants is held every year to coincide with the London Book Fair. Finalists are selected in national competitions organised locally by the British Council's overseas offices.
The finalists take part in an industry tour, which familiarises them with the dynamics of the UK publishing sector and introduces them to leading players in the industry. The finalists develop a network between themselves and with their peers in the UK sector. The finalists are also asked to select works from their country, which they then present at a [[book pitch]] to an expert jury and the general public.
All the finalists have now formed an alumni network which pioneers the importance of [[social network|business networking]] internationally for young entrepreneurs in the publishing business.
In 2007, the award was renamed International Young Publishing Entrepreneur, as part of a rebranding which coincided with the launch of the final awards in the programme. The British Council's Young Creative Entrepreneur programme now has nine international awards: communications, design, fashion, interactive, music, performing arts, publishing, screen and visual arts.
==IYPY 2004== Among finalists from [[Argentina]], [[Colombia]], [[India]], [[Lithuania]], [[Mexico]], [[Nigeria]], the [[Philippines]] and [[Poland]], the inaugural IYPY finalists went on a tour of the UK publishing industry to [[London]], [[Cambridge]], [[Tiptree]], [[Newcastle upon Tyne|Newcastle]], [[Edinburgh]], [[Aberystwyth]] and [[Hay-on-Wye]]. Mexican publisher Eduardo Rabasa of [[Editorial Sexto Piso]] was chosen as the inaugural winner. The award was presented by Jude Kelly, OBE, a British Council board member.
==IYPY 2005== Finalists of the 2005 edition came from Argentina, [[Bulgaria]], [[Latvia]], [[Lebanon]], Poland, [[Romania]], [[Russia]], [[South Africa]], [[Thailand]] and [[Turkey]], and Maria Deskur of [[Muchomor|Muchomor Publishers]] from Poland was chosen as the winner. Maria used her award to publish the teenage novel [[Operation Red Jericho]] by the British author [[Joshua Mowll]] in Polish. The award was presented by Lord Heseltine, of Haymarket Publishing.
==IYPY 2006== In 2006 ten creative young publishers, from Argentina, [[Colombia]], [[Jordan]], Lebanon, Lithuania, Mexico, [[Oman]], [[Slovenia]], South Africa and Thailand, came to the UK to present their work to an international jury chaired by Simon Winder, Publishing Director at [[Penguin Press]]. Joanna El-Mir from Lebanese children's publisher was chosen as the winner. The award was presented by Alistair Burtenshaw, the Director of London Book Fair.
==IYPY 2007== The 2007 event had finalists from Argentina, [[Egypt]], [[Hungary]], India, [[Malta]], Romania, Slovenia, South Africa and [[Syria]], and [[S. Anand]] of [[Navayana (publishing house)|Navayana Publishing]] in [[Chennai]], India was chosen as the winner. Anand leads the first independent imprint in India to deal exclusively with the issues of caste inequalities and identity politics. The event was preceded by a meeting of finalists from the previous editions, to officially form the IYPY alumni network. The award was presented by Liz Calder, Publishing Director of Bloomsbury.
==IYPE 2008== The 2008 event had finalists from Argentina, Egypt, India, Lebanon, Poland, Saudi Arabia, Slovenia, UAE and Yemen.For the first time, the award went to a book retailer, Nashwan Al-Maghafi, the Managing Director of Yemen Bookshop, a business that he established in 1995 when he was 19. The award was presented by Cherie Booth QC, the wife of the former British Prime Minister and a longstanding supporter of the programme.
==See also== * [[Creative industries]] * [[International Young Music Entrepreneur of the Year]] * [[International Young Design Entrepreneur of the Year]]
==External links== * [http://www.britishcouncil.org/arts-literature-londonbookfair-iypy2004.htm BritishCouncil.org], IYPY 2004 * [http://www.britishcouncil.org/arts-literature-londonbookfair2005.htm BritishCouncil.org], IYPY 2005 * [http://www.britishcouncil.org/arts-literature-iypy-2006.htm BritishCouncil.org], IYPY 2006 * [http://www.creativeconomy.org.uk/iypy CreativeEconomy.org.], IYPY 2007 * [http://www.creativeconomy.org.uk/iype08 CreativeEconomy.org], IYPE 2008
[[Category:Business and industry awards]] [[Category:Early career awards]] [[Category:British Council]]

'''John Peter van Gigch''' (1930 – August 29, 2006 in [[Sebastopol, California]]) was an American [[organizational theorist]] and Professor Emeritus in System Management at the [[California State University]].<ref>[http://www.worldcat.org/identities/lccn-n86-92185 Van Gigch, John P.] worldcat.org identities. Retrieved Nov 21, 2012.</ref>
== Life and work == Born in [[Argentina]] in 1930, Van Gigch transferred in the 1960s from a university to the States.<ref name="RK 06">Richard Kaufman (2006) JOHN VAN GIGCH in: ''[http://www.csus.edu/org/retirees/in_memory/04dMem2006.htm In Memoriam Archive for the Year 2006]''. csus.edu, 2006. Retrieved Nov 21, 2012</ref> In 1968 he received a PhD in [[Industrial Engineering]] from [[Oregon State University]] for his dissertation ''The Impact of Technology on the Mental Content of Work in Industrial Operations''.
In 1968 he started working at [[California State University]] at the School of Business and Public Administration. In the 1970s he became Professor Operations/Strategic Management, and head of the Department of Management, College of Business at the California State University. In 1993 he retired from the business school faculty.<ref name="RK 06"/> Until his death he remained an active member of the [[International Society for the Systems Sciences]], where he led the Special Integration Groups on Modeling and Metamodeling.<ref>Dennis Finlayson (2008) "Meta, macro and micro ethics: essay in honour of John van Gigch". In: ''Systems Research and Behavioral Science'', 25: 349–353. doi: 10.1002/sres.891</ref>
Van Gigch research interest was in the field of [[decision making]], [[systems design]], [[scientific modeling|modeling]] and [[metamodeling]]. In the 1970s he developed a new approach to organizational decision-making based on systems thinking together with the Dutch scientist [[Walter J.M. Kickert]], since 1990 professor of public management at Erasmus University Rotterdam.<ref>[[Walter J.M. Kickert]] and JP van Gigch (1979) "A metasystem approach to organizational decision-making". In: ''Management Science'', 1979</ref> In the 1980s he wrote some notable papers on the foundations of [[information system]]s as a science<ref>JP van Gigch, LL Pipino (1986) "In search of a paradigm for the discipline of information systems" in: ''Future computing systems'', 1986</ref><ref>JP Van Gigch, JL Le Moigne (1989) "A paradigmatic approach to the discipline of information systems". In: ''Behavioral Science'', 1989</ref> and the epistemological foundations of [[Operations Research]].<ref>JP Van Gigch (1989) "The potential demise of OR/MS: Consequences of neglecting epistemology". In: ''European journal of operational research'', 1989</ref> In his latter work he kept focused on "an epistemological inquiry about the foundations of knowledge of a scientific discipline".<ref>J.P Van Gigch (2003) ''Metadecisions: rehabilitating epistemology''. Intro.</ref>
== Publications == * 1971. ''Using systems analysis to implement cost-effectiveness and program budgeting in education''. With Richard E. Hill. * 1974. ''Applied General Systems Theory''. Harper & Row Publishers. Foreword by [[C. West Churchman]] * 1987. ''Decision making about decision making: metamodels and metasystems''. Edited by John P. van Gigch ; with a foreword by [[Stafford Beer]] * 1991. ''System Design Modeling and Metamodeling'' * 2003. ''Metadecisions: Rehabilitating Epistemology''. Springer * 2006. ''Wisdom, Knowledge, and Management''
== References == {{reflist|2}}
== External links == * [http://www.ifsr.org/index.php/tag/john-p-van-gigch/ John P. van Gigch], 1988
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gigch, John P. van}} [[Category:1930 births]] [[Category:2006 deaths]] [[Category:American business theorists]] [[Category:American systems scientists]] [[Category:Oregon State University alumni]] [[Category:California State University, Sacramento faculty]]

'''''La règle de non-cumul''''' is a principle of [[French law]] which regulates whether an action should be brought under [[contract law]] (''la responsibilité civile'') or [[tort law]] (''la responsibilité delictuelle'').
It states that where there is a contract, an action can only be brought under contract law and when there is no contract an action can only be brought under tort law.
==References== * Droit Civil, Brigitte Hess-Fallon - (2005) 8eme edition.
{{DEFAULTSORT:La regle de non-cumul}} [[Category:French business law]]
{{Europe-law-stub}}

{{About||the Malian newspaper|Les Échos (Mali)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox newspaper |name = Les Échos |logo = Logo Les Échos.svg |logo_size = 240px |image = [[File:Les Échos frontpage.JPG|260px|border]] |caption = |type = Daily financial newspaper |format = [[Berliner (format)|Berliner]] |foundation = {{start date and age|1908}} |owners = [[LVMH]] |headquarters = [[Paris]] |chiefeditor = Henri Gibier |political = [[Economic liberalism]] |opeditor = |publisher= Groupe Les Échos |circulation = 120,546 (July 2011-July 2012) |language = French |ISSN = 0153-4831 |website = [http://www.lesechos.fr lesechos.fr] }} '''''Les Échos''''' is the first daily [[France|French]] financial [[newspaper]], edited in [[Paris]] since 1908.
==History and profile== The paper was established as a monthly publication under the name of ''Les Échos de l’Exportation'' by the brothers Robert and [[Émile Servan-Schreiber]] in 1908.<ref name="urlLes Echos vendus">{{cite web |url=http://www.francetvinfo.fr/economie/medias/les-echos-vendus-a-lvmh-la-tribune-a-news-participations-les-rachats-font-flores-dans-la-presse-economique_220423.html |title="Les Echos" vendus à LVMH, "La Tribune" à... News Participations ? Les rachats font flores dans la presse économique |work= |accessdate=2016-08-02}}</ref><ref name="urlHistory of Groupe Les Echos">{{cite web |url=http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/groupe-les-echos-history/ |title=History of Groupe Les Echos – FundingUniverse |format= |work= |accessdate=2016-08-02}}</ref> It became a daily newspaper in 1928 and was renamed as ''Les Échos''.<ref>{{cite web|title=European News Resources|url=http://guides.nyu.edu/content.php?pid=74313&sid=704214|work=NYU Libraries|accessdate=24 January 2015}}</ref><ref name="urlLes Echos vendus"/><ref name="urlHistory of Groupe Les Echos"/> The newspaper was bought by the British media group [[Pearson PLC]] in 1988, and was sold to the French luxury goods conglomerate [[LVMH]] in November 2007.<ref>{{cite web|title=Les Echos|url=http://www.worldcrunch.com/source-partner/les-echos-15.html#.VHD-xFesUX4|work=Worldcrunch|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref><ref name=bbc>{{cite news|title=VMH buys Les Echos from Pearson|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7080079.stm|accessdate=22 November 2014|work=BBC|date=5 November 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=France -- Media Guide 2008|url=http://fas.org/irp/dni/osc/france-media.pdf|work=Open Source Center|accessdate=1 March 2015|date=16 July 2008}}</ref> The publisher of the paper is Groupe Les Échos.<ref name=euro/>
''Les Échos'' has a [[Liberalism|liberal]] stance and is published on weekdays.<ref name=euro>{{cite web|title=Les Echos|url=http://www.eurotopics.net/en/home/medienindex/media_articles/?frommedia=1371|work=Euro Topics|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> The paper is headquartered in Paris and has a website which was launched in 1996.<ref name=vox/><ref>{{cite web|title=Daily Newspapers: First in a Series on the French Media|url=http://www.wikileaks.ch/cable/2006/11/06PARIS7251.html|work=Wikileaks|accessdate=24 February 2015|date=6 November 2006|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150207141142/http://www.wikileaks.ch/cable/2006/11/06PARIS7251.html|archivedate=7 February 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The paper publishes economical analyses by leading economists, including [[Joseph Stiglitz]] and [[Kenneth Rogoff]].<ref name=vox>{{cite web|title=Les Echos|url=http://www.voxeurop.eu/en/content/source-information/71401-les-echos|work=Vox Europ|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref>
In September 2003 ''Les Échos'' switched from [[tabloid format]] to [[Berliner format]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Size matters... if you are a Brit|url=http://www.mediaweek.co.uk/article/516459/size-matters-brit|accessdate=23 February 2015|work=MediaWeek|date=13 July 2004}}</ref> In 2004, the newspaper won the [[European Project for Ice Coring in Antarctica|EPICA]] award.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.epica-awards.com/pages/pastresults2004_epicador_press.html|title=Epica d'Or 2004 (print)|year=2008|work=Epica Awards|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081205095633/http://www.epica-awards.com/pages/pastresults2004_epicador_press.html|archivedate=5 December 2008|accessdate=28 September 2013}}</ref>
In 2010, the coverage of ''Les Échos'' was expanded to cover such topics as innovations in science, technologies, green growth, medicine and health and skills concerning marketing and advertising, management, education, strategy and leadership, law and finance.<ref name=pub10>{{cite news|title=Business daily Les Echos offers a new model with a new layout and expands its digital offer|url=http://www.publicitas.com/singapore/media-news-events/news-detail/?newsid=43070&title=france-business-daily-les-echos-offers-a-new-model-with-a-new-layout-and-expands-its-digital-offer#.VHEGFVesUX4|accessdate=22 November 2014|work=Publicitas|date=7 September 2010}}</ref> The former separate sections of IT and communications were merged under the section of high tech and media.
In 2013 the newspaper started a project called LesEchos360, a business news aggregation platform.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Rachel McAthy|title=France's Les Echos launching business news aggregation|url=https://www.journalism.co.uk/news/france-s-les-echos-launching-business-news-aggregation/s2/a553361/|work=Journalism|accessdate=22 November 2014|date=21 June 2013}}</ref>
==Circulation== In 2000 ''Les Échos'' was the sixth best-selling newspaper in France with a circulation of 728,000 copies.<ref>{{cite book|editor1=Mary Kelly|editor2=Gianpietro Mazzoleni|editor3=Denis McQuail|title=The Media in Europe: The Euromedia Handbook|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yPS8edN_aJUC&pg=PA76|accessdate=24 April 2015|date=17 December 2003|publisher=SAGE Publications|isbn=978-1-4129-3260-8|page=76}}</ref> The 2009 circulation of the paper was 127,000 copies.<ref name=euro/> From July 2011 to July 2012 the paper had a circulation of 120,546 copies.<ref>{{cite news|title=New layout for Les Echos|url=http://www.publicitas.com/singapore/media-news-events/news-detail/?newsid=90566&title=france-new-layout-for-les-echos#.VHEHrFesUX4|accessdate=22 November 2014|work=Publicitas|date=7 November 2012}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{fr icon}} {{Official website|http://www.lesechos.fr/ }} *{{fr icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20110109011047/http://m.lesechos.fr/ ''Les Échos'' mobile website] *(in French) [https://solutions.lesechos.fr/ Les Echos Solutions website (Echos Business Services)] *{{en icon}} [http://www.rfi.fr/actuen/listes/001/liste_type_article_54.asp Regular French Press Review] - Radio France International

revision.comment: update & correction + sources: actually he did not accomplish his studies
revision.text:
'''Luigi Lucchini''' (21 January 1919 – 26 August 2013) was an [[Italian people|Italian]] businessman and steel executive.
The son of an iron craftsman, Lucchini was born in [[Casto, Lombardy|Casto]], [[Brescia]], [[Italy]] on 21 January 1919. He studied foreign languages at the [[Catholic University of Milan]] but dropped out of university due to financial difficulties;<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.comune.brescia.it/servizi/cimiteri/famedio/personaggiillustri/19992015/Pagine/Luigi-Lucchini.aspx|title=Luigi Lucchini. Imprenditore metallurgico, Cavaliere del lavoro, benefattore|website=Comune di Brescia (Municipality of Brescia)|access-date=27 January 2018|language=Italian}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bresciaoggi.it/territori/citt%C3%A0/e-39-morto-luigi-lucchini-addio-al-re-del-tondino-1.4212480|title=E' morto Luigi Lucchini. Addio al re del tondino|language=Italian|work=[[Bresciaoggi]]|location=[[Brescia]]|date=27 August 2013|access-date=29 January 2018}}</ref> then he worked as a teacher for a brief period and finally he took over his father's workshop in [[Val Sabbia]].<ref name=Stefanato>{{cite news|last=Paolo Stefanato|title=Lucchini, il re dell'acciaio che si fidava solo di Cuccia|url=http://www.ilgiornale.it/news/economia/lucchini-re-dellacciaio-che-si-fidava-solo-cuccia-945629.html|accessdate=27 August 2013|newspaper=[[Il Giornale]]|date=27 August 2013}}</ref> After [[World War II]] he realized his first extensions of the family business, installing a small mill for the production of [[rebar]].<ref name=bio>{{cite news|last=Matteo Meneghello|title=È morto Luigi Lucchini, ex presidente di Confindustria. Squinzi: scompare un protagonista del Dopoguerra|url=http://www.ilsole24ore.com/art/notizie/2013-08-26/morto-luigi-lucchini-presidente-151611.shtml?uuid=AbU1jWQI|accessdate=27 August 2013|newspaper=[[Il Sole 24 Ore]]|date=26 August 2013}}</ref><ref name=rep/> Between the 1970s and the 1980s, the company had its true season of expansion, with the acquisition of several production facilities in and outside Italy.<ref name=bio/>
In 1975 he was appointed [[Cavaliere del Lavoro]], and in later years he entered the Board of Directors of the [[Banca Commerciale Italiana]] (of which he became chairman), [[Montedison]] (chairman), Compart (chairman), [[Assicurazioni Generali]] (of which he became a member of the Executive Committee), [[Olivetti]], [[Mediobanca]] and [[Gemina]].<ref name=bio/><ref name=rep/>
From 1978 to 1983 Lucchini was president of the Industrial Association of Brescia and a member of the board of [[Confindustria]], of which he became the president in 1984.<ref name=bio/><ref name=rep>{{cite news|last=Redazione|title=E' morto Luigi Lucchini, re dell'acciaio italiano|url=http://www.repubblica.it/economia/2013/08/26/news/e_morto_luigi_lucchini_re_dell_acciaio_italiano-65320418/|accessdate=27 August 2013|newspaper=[[La Repubblica]]|date=26 August 2013}}</ref> From 1980 to 1982 Lucchini was also part of the [[EEC]] Consultative Committee in representation of the European private steel producers.<ref name=rep/> After the sale of the majority stake of the company to [[Severstal]] in 2005, Lucchini remained honorary president of the group until 2010, when he announced his retirement.<ref name=bio/><ref name=rep/>
==Honors== * Honoris causa degree in Economics, [[University of Brescia]], 18 June 1998 <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.unibs.it/ateneo/premi-e-riconoscimenti|title=Premi e riconoscimenti - Lauree Honoris Causa|access-date=27 January 2018|language=Italian}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ilgiorno.it/brescia/cronaca/2013/08/26/939953-Morto-Luigi-Lucchini.shtml|title=E' morto Luigi Lucchini Fu presidente di Confindustria|language=Italian|work=[[Il Giorno (newspaper)|Il Giorno]]|location=[[Brescia]]|date=26 August 2013|access-date=27 January 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * Roberto Chiarini, ''Falco e colomba. Luigi Lucchini si racconta'', Marsilio, 2009. {{ISBN|8831799452}}.
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lucchini, Luigi}}

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}}
{{Infobox person |name=Mark Phooi |image=Mark Phooi at age 45, April 2007.jpg |caption=Mark Phooi in April 2007 }}
'''Mark Phooi Peck Lye''' (born 22 August 1962) is a Singaporean entrepreneur in the design industry. He is the founder and CEO of First Media Pte Ltd (FM), a holding company that manages a collection of design agencies and design institutions.<ref>[http://www.firstmedia.com.sg Objective of First Media] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103022034/http://www.firstmedia.com.sg/ |date=3 November 2012 }}</ref>
His first business venture at the age of 27 was a design agency he started on his own with a capital of S$2,000. He called it Lancer Design,<ref>{{cite news |first=Swati |last=Chaudhary |title=First Media eyes more M&As |location = Singapore |work=The Business Times |date=18 July 2006 }}</ref> deriving the name Lancer from the word "freelancer".<ref>{{cite news |first=Rossara |last=Jamil |title=Visionary By Design |location = Singapore |work=Marketing Magazine |date= September 2006 }}</ref> At the age of 32, he earned his first million.
In 2006, Phooi founded First Media Design School (FMDS), a progressive private educational institution specialising in the field of design. In August 2011, FMDS was awarded the Council for Private Education's (CPE) four-year EduTrust mark.<ref>{{cite news |first=Kelly |last=Tan |title=Surviving the school of hard knocks |location = Singapore |work=The Business Times |date=1 May 2012 }}</ref>
==Early life and education== Phooi was born in Singapore. His father worked as a contractor for [[PSA International]] and his mother was a contract labourer. At the age of 9, he joined [[The Singapore Scout Association]](SSA) as a Sea Scout and at the age of 12, he became a qualified lifeguard.
Phooi attended his secondary school education from the age of 13 to 16 at [[Tanglin Secondary School]]. At the age of 24, he enrolled into a Fine Arts diploma program at the [[Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts]](NAFA), but switched to a Graphic Design pathway soon after. He graduated from NAFA in 1989 at the age of 27.<ref>{{cite news |first=Rossara |last=Jamil |title=Visionary By Design |location = Singapore |work=Marketing Magazine |date= September 2006 }}</ref> In 2002, he graduated from the [[University of New South Wales]] with a Master of Design.
==Career==
===Lifeguard and swimming coach=== While waiting to be enlisted into the National Service, Phooi worked for a year as a lifeguard at Big Splash, a water theme park in Singapore that was launched in 1976.<ref>[http://www.everyplaces.com/singapore/singapore_attraction.html Fun Days Out] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130126133012/http://www.everyplaces.com/singapore/singapore_attraction.html |date=26 January 2013 }}</ref> During this period, he also taught swimming to a handful of students, aged between 6 and 10 years old, on a part-time basis.
While serving his term with the [[Singapore Armed Forces]], Phooi continued to coach swimming during his weekends to supplement his income. After his National Service term was completed, he started to teach on a full-time basis, only retiring from coaching at the age of 29.
Midway through his coaching career, Phooi embarked on a training program to attain the CLASS 1 Swimming Coach qualification. As part this program, he was attached to the [[People's Association]] swimming team, under the tutelage of the late Kee Soon Bee, a prolific national swimming coach. Kee was well known for being able to spot and groom competitive national swimmers such as [[Junie Sng]], [[Mark Chay]] and [[Joscelin Yeo]].<ref>[http://www.sportsmuseum.com.sg/heroes/roll_of_honour/coach/kee_soon_bee.html KEE SOON BEE] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111226061611/http://www.sportsmuseum.com.sg/heroes/roll_of_honour/coach/kee_soon_bee.html |date=26 December 2011 }}</ref>
===Designpreneur=== Phooi began his career as a designpreneur (entrepreneur in the design industry) by setting up Lancer Design in 1989.<ref>{{cite news |title=Cover Story: Mark Phooi |location = Singapore |work=The Executive |date=June 2007 }}</ref> During its early years, he was running the company as a one-man show, which meant that he had to adopt all the required roles to sustain his company, such as being the salesman, project coordinator, creative head, planner and administrator.
In 2002, Mark established First Media Pte Ltd (FM) as a holding company for his design firms and design schools.<ref>{{cite news |title=The Enterprise 50 Awards 2005 |location = Singapore |work=The Straits Times |date=24 January 2006 }}</ref> His design agencies specialised in various design and media disciplines, such as corporate design, interactive media, events, publishing and advertising and promotion. Companies under the First Media brand include Lancer Design and Mint Editions in Singapore, Brand Smart in China, Auromedia, Discover Jakarta and Imago in Indonesia, BnBc Advertising Sdn Bhd and BnBc Events and Promotions Sdn Bhd in Malaysia, Clever Brand Strategy Co. Ltd in Taiwan, and P.0.P. House in Thailand.<ref>[http://www.firstmedia.com.sg First Media Companies] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103022034/http://www.firstmedia.com.sg/ |date=3 November 2012 }}</ref>
In 2005, FM was one of only five recipients to receive the Enterprise 50 Award – an annual business award recognising Singapore's most promising privately held companies.<ref>{{cite news |first=Swati |last=Chaudhary |title=First Media eyes more M&As |location = Singapore |work=The Business Times |date=18 July 2006 }}</ref>
In 2006, Mark was awarded one of the Top Entrepreneurs of the Year Awards (organised by the Association of Small and Medium Enterprises (ASME) and the Rotary Club of Singapore) – one of the highest business award recognitions in Singapore, and one that no trained designer had ever attained previously.<ref>{{cite news |title=Cover Story: Mark Phooi |location = Singapore |work=The Executive |date=June 2007 }}</ref>
In 2007, Mark was also selected as one of the finalists in Singapore's top design accolade – the President's Design Award.
===Principal=== In 2006, Mark founded First Media Design School (FMDS), a boutique private design institution that offers diploma, advanced diploma and degree programs in the areas [[Graphic design]], [[Multimedia]] and Fashion design. Its [[Bachelor's degree]] program is conferred by the [[University of the West of England]](UWE).
The institution's mission statement specifies that FMDS strives to cultivate a new generation of 'whole brain' trained, industry-ready designers who possess both creative and commercial cognitive abilities, through its holistic design thinking and design management teaching system.<ref>[http://www.firstmedia.edu.sg/aboutus/visionmission.html Vision & Mission] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130303042613/http://www.firstmedia.edu.sg/aboutus/visionmission.html |date=3 March 2013 }}</ref> Its teaching methodology is partly derived from the [[Herrmann Brain Dominance Instrument]] system.
The students enrolled in FMDS consist of a mixture of local and international students, mostly from Indonesia and China.<ref>{{cite news |first=U-wen |last=Lee |title=Designing a career |location = Singapore |work=Today |date=11 September 2006 }}</ref> FMDS equips career starters and career switchers with the necessary skills to go from mere practitioner to business-owner.<ref>{{cite news |first=U-wen |last=Lee |title=Designing a career |location = Singapore |work=Today |date=11 September 2006 }}</ref> In an interview in 2006, when Mark was asked about how he envisions FMDS to be different from other design schools in Singapore, he said:<ref>{{cite news |first=Swati |last=Chaudhary |title=First Media eyes more M&As |location = Singapore |work=The Business Times |date=18 July 2006 }}</ref>
{{quote|We will differentiate ourselves by developing designers to become design managers. This is what is lacking in the industry today. There are many designers but not enough creative managers. We have thousands of graduates every year with few job opportunities. Not only will we create enterprising graduates, but we will also offer them jobs in our companies.}}
==Books== In 2013, Mark co-authored ''[[Think like a Sage, Work like a Fool, Act like a Criminal]]'' ({{ISBN|978-981-07-5167-8}}), which consists of his biography, and a compilation of business theories, life lessons and personal reflections garnered from the early years of his career as a designpreneur to the present.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.firstmedia.com.sg First Media Pte Ltd Official Website]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Phooi, Mark}} [[Category:Singaporean businesspeople]] [[Category:Singaporean people of Chinese descent]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Singaporean educators]] [[Category:Education International]] [[Category:Singaporean Christians]] [[Category:1962 births]] [[Category:21st-century Singaporean educators]] [[Category:20th-century Singaporean businesspeople]]
